p: In this research, we also identified different inactivating mutations was detected among all mysticete species in ACPT gene, among which two shared single-base sites deletion were found on exon 4 and 5 of ACPT among all living baleen whales, which result in loss of function. Some studies have confirmed that ACPT gene is responsible for the development of enamel, and mutations can also lead to amelogenesis imperfecta ( Choi et al., 2016; Seymen et al., 2016; Smith et al., 2017a). Similar to the result of Meredith et al. (2011), our study supported the hypothesis that mineralized teeth were lost or degenerated in the common ancestor of all extant baleen whales.
